Subject: Re: New HyperNEAT Paper in the Domain of Checkers
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=200957992; y=A9-I2yOM8So5MPZhSKpr9i5luPxiweyCLl62NrkOOM-g3yRg3A

Hey Stephen,

Great questions!  We'll have to think about some of them for =
awhile
but here's a few answers:

The reason why I chose to use a separate =
output for each connection
layer instead of using a 3-dimensional CPPN is b=
ecause I wanted to
separate the network for each layer.  If you use the 3-D=
 CPPN method,
then the two layers are only distinguished by the values of '=
z'. 
Because I'm only using two layers, I wanted to make sure that each
lay=
er did some unique processing.  If there was only one output, it
would be h=
arder for the connection layers to distinguish themselves as
they would be =
too dependent.  In the worst case, z1 and z2 inputs are
not used and the tw=
o layers are exactly the same. I haven't done any
empirical tests on which =
method is better so I do not have any
evidence to back my claim, but it's m=
y intuition.

I haven't tried any computer opponents other than Xcheckers. =
 I have
had my friends and people in the lab play against the HyperNEAT
opp=
onent and it is definitely better than all of us :-).  I would like
to rele=
ase a binary version so people can play the opponents at
different generati=
ons and see the change in performance.

One active area of interest is to f=
igure out how good a HyperNEAT
player is in a global sense.  In Chellapilla=
 & Fogel's paper, they
played human opponents in checkers on MSN Gaming Zon=
e online and got
an expert rating on that game server.  The problem with th=
is is that
it is very time consuming to play games by hand. It would not be=

feasible for me to test several individuals in this way.

I have experimen=
ted with coevolution, but I need to solve the
aforementioned problem before=
 I can say anything about the performance
of the evolved individuals.

--- =
In neat@yahoogroups.com, Stephen Waits <steve@...> wrote:
>
> 
> On Apr 11,=
 2008, at 9:38 PM, Kenneth Stanley wrote:
> > Jason Gauci and I are pleased=
 to share with you new results with
> > HyperNEAT  in our new paper to appe=
ar in the Twenty-Third AAAI
> > Conference on Artificial Intelligence (2008=
), "A Case Study on the
> > Critical Role of Geometric Regularity in Machin=
e Learning."
> 
> 
> Cool, I enjoyed the paper, thanks Jason and Ken.
> 
> =
I have a few questions:
> 
> * Was the 4in/2out CPPN arbitrarily chosen?
> =
* Why not a 6in/1out (xyz, xyz, out) - which seems more natural to me?
> * =
Was more than one CPPN configuration tried?  What was the process?
> * Was =
more than one substrate configuration tried?  ...
> * What was the full con=
nection pattern through the substrate?  You  
> mention the 129 nodes (whic=
h makes sense), but what are the 3979  
> connections?
> * Did you try agai=
nst any opponents other than Xcheckers?
> * Have you experimented with coev=
olution?
> 
> Thanks again for the great work.
> --
> Stephen Waits
> steve=
@...
> http://swaits.com/
